Award.AwardTitle: The Evolutionary Consequences of Interspecific Aggression
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aggression between species is extremely common and, when it causes divergence of traits, can contribute to biodiversity. This project brings together theorists and empiricists from the United States and Mexico to investigate the role of interspecific aggression in evolutionary diversification. The project will develop and test theory to predict the evolutionary consequences of territorial aggression between species of Hetaerina damselflies. These brightly colored insects provide a tractable model in which the effects of interspecific aggression can be distinguished from those resulting from other processes. The project will use field experiments to inform and refine a detailed model of the workings of aggressive interactions in damselflies and will test this model against patterns of geographic variation in behavior and coloration and molecular measures of species divergence.

This project will unify previous work on species interactions and their roles in the creation of biodiversity and will develop a formal model framework to guide future research on the evolutionary consequences of interspecific aggression. The project will provide interdisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students and includes strong international collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aggression between species is extremely common and must be a major determinant of how populations diversify. Yet aggression is vastly understudied compared to other types of interactions between species. This project brought together theorists and empiricists to take key steps towards integration of theory and data in the study of aggression between species.

One of the products of this research is a flexible individual-based modeling framework that allows alternative modes of character displacement to be studied simultaneously. The first model based on this framework helped clarify the relationship between agonistic character displacement and reproductive character displacement. A second model showed that reproductive inference between species strongly affects the predicted outcome and can cause species to converge in species recognition traits.  These models were tested in a highly tractable group of insects (Hetaerina spp.), in which aggression and reproductive interference between species is commonplace. Field experiments were carried out at multiple locations in the United States and Mexico and genetic analyses were carried out to construct a species-level phylogeny for the group. Based on the first model, a key question for distinguishing between alternative character displacement processes is whether the same or different traits are used for mate recognition and competitor recognition. The results of a field experiment showed that different traits are used for competitor recognition and mate recognition in Hetaerina.  This eliminated reproductive character displacement as a viable explanation for observed patterns of divergence in male coloration and thereby strengthened the case for agonistic character displacement. To test the second model, field experiments were carried out to measure aggression and reproductive interference between species. The results showed a close correspondence between levels of reproductive interference and aggression across species, confirming a key prediction of the theory.

This project provided research training and funding for two doctoral students, both of whom completed their PhD’s and subsequently obtained post-doctoral research positions. One post-doctoral researcher participated in the project and subsequently obtained a tenure-track faculty position. Thirty two undergraduate students received on-hands research training and several carried out honors research projects and presented their findings in a research symposium, and several of them are now enrolled in graduate schools or health-related professional schools. This project also fostered collaboration between researchers in the United States and Mexico.

A website was created to disseminate the research findings to a broad audience (http://www.rubyspot.org) and a short film based on the project was shown at the National Evolutionary Synthesis Center’s Film Festival (http://vimeo.com/24805225).
